author: Gautam S Mengle
text:
2,500 personnel to focus on VIP security as city police goes into overdrive

Artisans work on their stall at the venue of Make in India week on the eve of its inaugural, in Mumbai, on Friday.— Photo: PTI

In a bid to ensure comprehensive monitoring of all Make in India Week venues, Mumbai police has installed more than 100 Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) cameras as part of the security cover for the high-profile event, which will be inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Saturday.

The Make in India Week, organised to bring foreign investors and administrative agencies together to facilitate ease of doing business in the country, will see high-level political dignitaries and over 100 delegates from foreign countries in attendance.

Taking into account the current terror-sensitive environment, police officials said 90 CCTV cameras have been installed all over the MMRDA grounds at the Bandra Kurla Complex, where various events will be held next week, while 22 cameras will cover the Girgaum sea face. The Gateway of India gets six security cameras, they added.

A senior police officer said the cameras will cover interiors as well as the perimeter and external areas of the venues. Dedicated control rooms have been set up at the venues, where the camera feed will be monitored round-the-clock by civic and police officials. These control rooms will also be in constant touch with the police control room.

Regional Quick Response Teams (QRT), formed after the 26/11 terror attacks, will be at the forefront of security arrangements, as these commandoes are trained in modern weaponry and battle tactics, undergo refresher courses and practice sessions on a regular basis, officials said.

“A separate division of around 2,500 police personnel has been formed to focus solely on VIP security. Each VIP will have his own security detail, and we have also arranged for around 100 vehicles so that each VIP gets his own convoy to ensure safe and secure movement in and out of the venues,” another officer said.

While the police are mainly relying on their 55,000 personnel, officials said Force One, another fighting force created post-26/11, might be brought in if the need arises for additional manpower. The police are also in touch with state and central intelligence agencies to keep abreast of intelligence alerts, while anti-terror cells of all police stations are providing daily updates from the ground, sources said.
title: CCTV cameras, quick response teams to secure Make in India event
